habits: Non-smoker, occasional alcohol consumption, sedentary lifestyle
medicalHistory: Hypertension (diagnosed 10 years ago, controlled with medication)
Type 2 Diabetes (diagnosed 5 years ago, controlled with oral hypoglycemics)
familyHistory:
Mother: Rheumatoid Arthritis
- Father: Coronary Artery Disease
currentSymptoms:
- Persistent cough (worsening over the past 3 months)
- Shortness of breath (especially during physical activity)
- Fatigue (increasing over the past 3 months)
- Occasional chest tightness (more frequent in the past month)
- Wheezing (noticed occasionally, especially at night)
clinicalNotes: Entry 1: January 15 2023  Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath and wheezing. History: Patient reports increased frequency of asthma attacks over the past two weeks, particularly at night. Using rescue inhaler 4-5 times daily. Examination: Audible wheezing, decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Assessment: Severe asthma exacerbation. Plan: Prescribed oral corticosteroids for 5 days, increased dosage of inhaled corticosteroids, advised use of peak flow meter, follow-up in 2 weeks.

Entry 2: February 10, 2023  Chief Complaint: Persistent cough and chest tightness. History: Patient reports moderate improvement but still experiencing daily symptoms. Using rescue inhaler 2-3 times daily. Examination: Mild wheezing, no signs of respiratory distress. Assessment: Partially controlled severe asthma. Plan: Continued inhaled corticosteroids, added long-acting beta-agonist, referred to pulmonologist for further evaluation, follow-up in 1 month.

Entry 3: March 15 2023  Chief Complaint: Improved symptoms but occasional shortness of breath. History: Patient reports significant improvement, using rescue inhaler once daily. No nighttime awakenings. Examination: Clear lung sounds, no wheezing. Assessment: Well-controlled severe asthma. Plan: Continue current medication regimen, scheduled spirometry test, follow-up in 3 months or sooner if symptoms worsen.
otherInfo:
- Recent increase in use of rescue inhaler (from once a week to almost daily)
- No recent infections or respiratory illnesses
- No recent changes in medication
- No known allergies
